articles.headline: On Day 3, Justices Weigh What-Ifs of Health Ruling
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered several possible approaches if the individual mandate is removed from the law and also examined an expansion of Medicaid.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered several possible approaches if the individual mandate is removed from the law and also examined an expansion of Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after the Supreme Court suggested that President Obama’s health care law might be in danger of being held unconstitutional, the justices on Wednesday turned their attention to the practical consequences and political realities of such a ruling.

articles.headline: Business Bets on the G.O.P. May Be Backfiring
articles.snippet: Big business groups spent millions to help Republicans win control of the House in 2010, but the return has not always met expectations.
articles.abstract: Big business groups spent millions to help Republicans win control of the House in 2010, but the return has not always met expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Big business groups like the Chamber of Commerce spent millions of dollars in 2010 to elect Republican candidates running for the House. The return on investment has not always met expectations.

articles.headline: A Bevy of Beauties, and So PC
articles.snippet: An ultrabook is essentially a MacBook Air that runs Windows — but don’t tell Intel that.
articles.abstract: An ultrabook is essentially a MacBook Air that runs Windows — but don’t tell Intel that.

articles.headline: Academic Built Case for Mandate in Health Care Law
articles.snippet: Jonathan Gruber, a professor at M.I.T., helped persuade the Obama administration that everyone should be required to get health insurance.
articles.abstract: Jonathan Gruber, a professor at M.I.T., helped persuade the Obama administration that everyone should be required to get health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Massachusetts, California came calling. So did Connecticut, Delaware, Kansas, Minnesota, Oregon, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

articles.headline: Fracas on JetBlue Flight Shows Gap in Screening
articles.snippet: After a captain acted erratically on a flight, some pilots said annual medical exams were not thorough and did not typically include psychological evaluations.
articles.abstract: After a captain acted erratically on a flight, some pilots said annual medical exams were not thorough and did not typically include psychological evaluations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airplane cockpits are meant to be the last line of defense from outside aggressors. But what if the threat comes from the cockpit itself?

articles.headline: Facelift Project for Hollywood Stirs Divisions
articles.snippet: A rezoning plan that would turn parts of Hollywood into a mini-city has won the support of key Los Angeles officials and set off a storm of opposition from residents.
articles.abstract: A rezoning plan that would turn parts of Hollywood into a mini-city has won the support of key Los Angeles officials and set off a storm of opposition from residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood, once a sketchy neighborhood in a spiral of petty crime and decay, has been well on its way over the past 10 years to becoming a bustling tourist destination and nightlife district. But now it is on the verge of another transformation: to a decidedly un-Californian urban enclave pierced by skyscrapers, clustered around public transportation and animated pedestrian street life.

articles.headline: Stock Market Flaws Not So Rare, Data Shows
articles.snippet: The breakdown on the BATS Global Markets exchange was stunning, but market disruptions have been common enough to rattle some investors’ confidence. A review of industry data shows that disruptions large and small are a daily occurrence.
articles.abstract: The breakdown on the BATS Global Markets exchange was stunning, but market disruptions have been common enough to rattle some investors’ confidence. A review of industry data shows that disruptions large and small are a daily occurrence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock market disruptions like the ones last week that temporarily shut down part of the nation’s third-largest exchange and briefly halted the trading of Apple shares are more common than investors may think.

articles.headline: Neighbors Said to Be at Violent Odds in Syrian Crackdown
articles.snippet: Refugees who have fled to Lebanon offered a rare firsthand account of the unfolding tumult in western Syria as an intensive bombardment of communities continues.
articles.abstract: Refugees who have fled to Lebanon offered a rare firsthand account of the unfolding tumult in western Syria as an intensive bombardment of communities continues.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL QAA, Lebanon — Sunni Muslims who have fled Syria described a government crackdown that is more pervasive and more sectarian than previously understood, with civilians affiliated with President Bashar al-Assad’s minority religious sect shooting at their onetime neighbors as the military presses what many Sunnis see as a campaign to force them to flee their homes and villages in some sections of the country.

articles.headline: France Suggests Deal Is Near on Tapping Oil Reserve
articles.snippet: The French prime minister said there were “good prospects” that developed nations would soon reach an agreement on tapping strategic oil reserves in a bid to lower gasoline prices.
articles.abstract: The French prime minister said there were “good prospects” that developed nations would soon reach an agreement on tapping strategic oil reserves in a bid to lower gasoline prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — François Fillon, the French prime minister, suggested Thursday that a deal was near among developed countries, including the United States, to tap strategic petroleum reserves to reduce gasoline prices.
